unkerpaulie

I think bonaparte's point was that religion, which is a tool created by the rich and powerful, was made so that the rich can stay rich and in power and maintain their oppression on the not-rich. So of course in keeping with their self-interest goals, they put systems in place to make sure they stayed alive. Religion appeals to the not-rich because it advertises hope that one day they too will become rich and powerful like their leaders.
 
 The attitude of "to hell with the rich" is a stupid and hypocritical one. Noone here can say with a straight face that they do not aspire to be rich. The entire thrust of the "self-improvement" movement is the pursuit of prosperity and the comforts and benefits it grants. If we believe that a richer you means a better you, then we are implying that richer is better. I have absolutelyno disdain for the rich nor the schemes they employ to become rich, I would be dishonest if I said I did. The important distinction between the rich and the not rich is not the value of their assets, but the mindset that being wealthy is ok. As demonstrated in this thread, the not rich think that the rich are evil and therefore associate very negative connotations with wealth. And guess what, that's exactly the product that religion puts out, whether you're a theist or not. As long as you think that its bad to be rich (or that the rich in general are bad), the negative association will persist and the gap between the rich and not rich will continue to expand.
LetsReason

It isn't that all religion encourages not killing the rich, it's that religions encouraging killing the rich (communism) quickly destroy the societies they inhabit, leaving only the other ones behind.

 
 The New Testament says that all authority derives from God, and therefore one must submit to authority no matter what. The slave should not try to get free from his master. The people must submit to a tyrant.
 
 Calvinistic Christianity preaches that being rich is a sign that a person is one of God's Elect. The rich are one's betters.
 
 These are examples of how religion protects those who oppress others.
 
 Napoleon was referring to the reason why the French Revolution executed not only the rich (ig)nobles, but also the clergy that supported them.
 
 Today, the quality of living of French employees far exceeds the quality of living of American employees: shorter working hours, more benefits, longer vacations, health-care guaranteed, better education, etc. The French also have a higher quality infra-structure: faster trains, faster internet, etc. Why? Because their government spends more money for the common good, rather than just pretending (as our Religious Right-wing encourages us to do) that a focus on aiding the rich get richer will have a decent trickle down benefit for all.

 You say that you have absolutely no disdain for the schemes employed by the rich to become rich. 
 
 I don't aspire to become rich by oppressing or cheating or hurting people. I think that only a scoundrel would aspire to that, or approve of that aspiration in others. Being wealthy is O.K. to a point, but the point where it ceases to be O.K. is when it has a destructive effect upon others. When the greed of the wealthy starts wars, crashes economies, and deprives others of freedom or health, then that greed is a public menace and it must be reigned in.

unkerpaulie

You say that you have absolutely no disdain for the schemes employed by the rich to become rich. 
 
 I don't aspire to become rich by oppressing or cheating or hurting people. I think that only a scoundrel would aspire to that, or approve of that aspiration in others. Being wealthy is O.K. to a point, but the point where it ceases to be O.K. is when it has a destructive effect upon others. When the greed of the wealthy starts wars, crashes economies, and deprives others of freedom or health, then that greed is a public menace and it must be reigned in.

 
 Unfortunately for many of us, we rely on the media to tell us what is going on in reality, the very media that is run by the very same rich that we are discussing now. So we have the tenancy to think that rich people are inherently oppressive and evil, because this is the picture we are fed. Its not an accident that this is what we are taught about the rich, nor the emotional associations with money that it creates. The systems of organized religion, public education and mass media are all designed to perpetuate the image in the minds of the citizens that being rich is linked to negativity at some essential level. And that's exactly what happens. If we were to learn that most rich people are actually honest, ethical and charitable it would create a conflict with what we believe and want to believe. We would rather think that the rich philanthropist is the exception rather than the rule. We would like to assume that the rich is bad at some fundamental level because it helps us feel good about ourselves being not rich, which is exactly what the rich want.
 
 I don't see it as a system to dispose, I see it as something to learn from and adapt to.
